title: 105_s1769
content: The text chunk discusses appropriations for the International Monetary Fund for the fiscal year ending September 30, 1998. It includes funds for loans to the IMF under the New Arrangements to Borrow, with a specified dollar amount. Additionally, it mentions the use of previously appropriated funds for the General Arrangements to Borrow. For an increase in the United States quota in the International Monetary Fund by 10,622,500,000 Special Drawing Rights. Section 101 of the Act prohibits the use of funds for the International Monetary Fund until certain conditions are met, including compliance with international trade obligations, elimination of government-directed lending, and guaranteeing non-discriminatory treatment in debt. Sec. 102 of the Act requires the Secretary of the Treasury to certify that the International Monetary Fund will provide access to information to the Comptroller General. Additionally, the Secretary must report on the implementation of non-discriminatory treatment in debt resolution proceedings. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Comptroller General and the U.S. Executive Director of the Fund, shall develop a plan for public access to information and documents related to the Fund's operations and programs. The Secretary of the Treasury will submit an annual report on the publication of Letters of Intent and Article IV consultation documents. An International Financial Institution Advisory Commission will be established, including former Secretaries of the Treasury, to report on the future role of the International Monetary Fund. The International Monetary Fund, International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, and World Trade Organization may consider consolidation for better management and activities. A conference will be called to discuss possible merger, structure, and capacity to contribute to economic growth and stability. Reports will be submitted following the extension of agreements or resource uses by the International Monetary Fund. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the U.S. Executive Director of the International Monetary Fund, must submit a report to the appropriate committees detailing the borrower's rules, private sector investors' burden, and the Fund's strategy for repayment of resources. The Secretary of the Treasury must report to the appropriate committees on the borrower's repayment of the Fund's resources, efforts to meet banking supervision standards, and recipients of resources indirectly supported by the Fund. The Secretary of the Treasury must report to Congress on South Korea, Indonesia, Thailand, and the Philippines. Certification conditions include no IMF support for specific industries in Korea and monitoring of corporate implementation. The Treasury has monitored the implementation of Corporate Governance provisions in South Korea's stabilization program. Certifications must be made before disbursement of any Fund resources, with the Secretary of the Treasury opposing further funds if certification is not given. Annual certifications are required. The 1998 Supplemental Appropriations Act for the International Monetary Fund requires annual certifications to be made as long as Fund contributions are outstanding to the borrower country. The Act defines "appropriate committees" and may be cited as such.
